The ‘chlamys’ was an upper ent worn by the Greeks, a light sort of shawl thrown loosely over the body in a variety of ways, of which a specimen is seen in the Belvedere Apollo. The Romans did not wear it till the time of the empire‚ and it was never more than an occasional - garment at Rome. Lucullus it seems had brought with him a number of a oostly kind from Asia, where they were worn in the Greek cities. 'What the repre- sentation may have been for which the praetor wanted these ‘chlamydes' is not certain, but Greek characters must have been introduced.
